docs.lead_paragraph: Now, the gloves come off. The Gore campaign upped the ante on the air yesterday with the most relentlessly hostile commercial it has yet produced, a 30-second spot that responds to the Bush campaign's attacks on Vice President Al Gore, by questioning whether Gov. George W. Bush has what it takes to be president. PRODUCER -- The Campaign Company

headline.main: Commercial Attacking Bush Is Gore's Most Hostile Yet

docs.abstract: Appraisal of latest advertisement from Gore campaign, most relentlessly hostile commercial it has yet produced, questioning whether Gov George W Bush has what it takes to be president; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Now, the gloves come off. The Gore campaign upped the ante on the air yesterday with the most relentlessly hostile commercial it has yet produced, a 30-second spot that responds to the Bush campaign's attacks on Vice President Al Gore, by questioning...

docs.lead_paragraph: Marlo Thomas has the right idea. An ardent Democrat, she went on the ''Today'' show Thursday to reprimand her husband, Phil Donahue, for helping Ralph Nader spread the fallacious message that it makes no difference whether Al Gore or George W. Bush wins the presidency. Ms. Thomas set an admirable example when she said the refusal to recognize profound differences between the two candidates had made her ''come out fighting.'' Her action ought to signal Gore supporters everywhere to put on a burst of energy and not be intimidated by the triumphalist theater of the Bush campaign. Borrowing a page from Ronald Reagan's playbook, Governor Bush is trying to act as if he has this contest locked up. But in fact, this presidential election is up for grabs. With four days left to campaign, Vice President Gore is ahead, gaining or highly competitive in the swing states that will decide the outcome. The polls are deceptive at this point. Mr. Bush has maintained a one- to four-point lead nationwide for several weeks by pumping his margins in Texas and other states that are safely in his pocket. But the state-by-state outlook and the electoral-vote arithmetic are much better for Mr. Gore. He is ahead in Florida in some polls, the one megastate other than Texas that was supposed to be a sure thing for Mr. Bush. The vice president is leading or competitive in crucial states like Illinois, Minnesota, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. He is also even in Missouri and Oregon, where an energetic effort by Democrats to counter the Nader threat could put Mr. Gore over the top.

headline.main: Al Gore in the Home Stretch

docs.abstract: Editorial urges supporters of Vice Pres Al Gore to put on burst of energy as campaign winds down, and not be intimidated by 'triumphalist theater' of Bush campaign; accuses Gov George W Bush of pretending to have campaign locked up, when contest is still tossup; notes Gore is still ahead, gaining or highly competitive in swing states that will decide outcome (M)
docs.snippet: Marlo Thomas has the right idea. An ardent Democrat, she went on the ''Today'' show Thursday to reprimand her husband, Phil Donahue, for helping Ralph Nader spread the fallacious message that it makes no difference whether Al Gore or George W. Bush...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George W. Bush used a trip through the politically pivotal Midwest today to deride Vice President Al Gore's proposals for Medicare and prescription drugs as the nostrums of a man with a dangerously robust appetite for federal regulation. Aggressively delving into an issue that is considered one of the Democrats' strongest suits, Mr. Bush said that his own prescription drug plan would give elderly people new choices, while Mr. Gore's would simply give them new rules. And this, Mr. Bush implied, was symptomatic of Mr. Gore's approach to health care in general.

headline.main: Bush Assails Gore Proposals On Health Care

docs.abstract: Gov George W Bush derides Vice Pres Al Gore's proposals for Medicare and prescription drugs as nostrums of man who likes federal regulation; Bush, campaigning in Wisconsin, in politically pivotal Midwest, delves into issue that is considered one of Democrats' strongest suits; Bush says his own prescription drug plan would give elderly new choices, while Gore's would give them new rules; Bush ties Gore to failed health care plan championed in 1993 by Hillary Rodham Clinton; Bush receives surprise endorsement from Ross Perot, whose candidacy in 1992 possibly spoiled re-election effort of Bush's father, Pres George Bush; Bush's day is jarred by news report of his 1976 arrest in Maine for driving under influence of alcohol; Bush confirms incident, expresses his regret, then questions why such information is coming out now, only five days from election day; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Gov. George W. Bush used a trip through the politically pivotal Midwest today to deride Vice President Al Gore's proposals for Medicare and prescription drugs as the nostrums of a man with a dangerously robust appetite for federal regulation.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Facing new questions about whether his wealth would influence his politics, Jon S. Corzine, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate in New Jersey, today restated his vow to place his investments in a blind trust if he is elected. Mr. Corzine renewed the pledge, first made in his primary campaign last spring, after the Associated Press reported today that the bulk of his wealth was tied up in Goldman Sachs stock and that he was prohibited by the company from selling it for at least three years. Because of that restriction, the A.P. report said, Mr. Corzine is unable to fulfill his campaign promise of not knowing about the day-to-day financial performance of the biggest element in his investment portfolio.

headline.main: Despite Stock Sale Limits, Corzine Pledges Blind Trust

docs.lead_paragraph: At the giant DaimlerChrysler engine plant here, 75 volunteers from the United Automobile Workers distributed a leaflet today seeking to reassure the factory's employees, many of whom hunt on weekends, that Vice President Al Gore's gun control proposals would in no way hurt sportsmen. In Florida, labor is deluging union retirees with mailings saying that Gov. George W. Bush's privatization proposal could endanger their Social Security benefits and that Mr. Gore would do more to cushion the cost of prescription drugs.

headline.main: Labor Tailors Its Vote-for-Gore Message, State by State

docs.abstract: Organized labor is making its biggest political push ever, relying increasingly on customized, state-by-state messages to get out vote for Vice Pres Al Gore; Steven Rosenthal, AFL-CIO's political director, says while message is being tailored to different regions and different types of workers, singular message is that there is stark contrast between Bush, who is antilabor and antiworker, and Gore, who has long been good friend of workers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An online health-care company is unveiling a wireless service today that has all the characteristics of a nagging mother, cell-phone style. WellMed, a Web company that delivers personalized health information to consumers, is offering a wireless messaging system that alerts users when they should be taking a dose of medication, getting a vaccine or even heading to the gym. The alerts arrive on the user's cell phone or pager, usually accompanied by a beep.

headline.main: Here's a Nagging Reminder: It's Time for Your Medicine

docs.abstract: Web company WellMed offers wireless messaging system that reminds subscribers when they should take a dose of medicine, receive a vaccine or go work out at gym; digital cellular telephone is required for subscription usage (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK THE BRONX: METROCARD THEFT ALLEGED A 12-year-old boy has been charged with grand larceny and possession of stolen property after a transit officer saw him take dozens of MetroCards from a defective vending machine at a subway station in the Bronx, the police said. The boy was removing the cards from a malfunctioning machine, which dispensed a new card each time he swiped an old card through it, said Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman. He said the boy had 79 MetroCards at the time of his arrest on Tuesday night. C. J. Chivers (NYT) MANHATTAN: USED MATTRESSES Undercover work by the Department of Consumer Affairs has found widespread abuse of state rules governing the sale of mattresses, with several stores illegally selling used merchandise. Although used but refurbished mattresses can be sold, they must be marked with tags, and the vendors must be licensed as secondhand dealers. Jane S. Hoffman, the consumer affairs commissioner, said 23 of 31 stores visited had violated the law. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City is failing to collect on millions of dollars worth of ambulance bills each year because of a poorly organized and badly managed collection effort, according to an audit released yesterday by state Comptroller H. Carl McCall. ''What the New York City Fire Department does best -- better than any other fire department in the world -- is save lives,'' Mr. McCall said in a statement. ''What we learned is that the department needs a great deal of help with the business side of its operations.''

headline.main: State Audit Finds Poor Bill Collection By Fire Department

docs.abstract: Audit released by NYS Comptroller H Carl McCall finds that New York City is failing to collect on millions of dollars worth of ambulance bills each year because of poorly organized and badly managed collection effort (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Never has this place meant so much to so many. ''This state has the ability to decide this close election,'' Vice President Al Gore told a throng of 5,000 here on Sunday. ''You have the ability to decide what this state decides.''

headline.main: In a Tossup State, This Town Turns Inside Out

docs.abstract: Lansing, Mich, tossup city in swing district in battleground state, is focus of intense presidential campaigning; recent interviews with voters suggest Gov George W Bush has slight edge; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Turning his opponent's language against him, Vice President Al Gore delivered a stinging rebuke of Gov. George W. Bush's tax-cut plan today, calling it a redistribution of wealth that amounted to ''class warfare on behalf of billionaires.'' Mr. Gore also continued a new line of attack on Mr. Bush, saying that his pledge to get along with people in Washington really meant that he would go along with the special interests.

headline.main: Gore Accuses Bush of Waging 'Class Warfare'

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore scores Gov George W Bush's tax-cut plan as 'class warfare on behalf of billionaires,' at expense of middle class, speech, Portland, Ore; holds Bush's proposal to eliminate estate tax would give $25 billion to nation's 3,000 wealthiest families; holds Bush's pledge to get along with people in Washington really means he will go along with special interests; Bush has accused Gore of conducting class warfare by appealing to 'working families;' recalls Sen John McCain's attack on Bush plan during Republican primaries; shifts some attention from Midwest to California, where polls show his lead has dwindled, and Oregon, where he and Bush are neck-and-neck; Bush is also campaigning in states; photos (M)
